content.webTitle: Harriet, what were you thinking? | Victoria Coren Mitchell

fields.headline: Harriet Harman, what were you thinking?
fields.bodyText: So Kim Kardashian has got this bum. That much I understand. I have actually seen Kim Kardashian’s bum. I don’t think I’m alone in that. It was quite interesting to look at. All bums are quite interesting to look at, because, in the general run of things, people keep them hidden. It’s like seeing someone’s bank statement. (Especially mine, which is all papery and red.) Beyond that, I’m baffled. I don’t understand. What? How? I don’t quite comprehend what Kim Kardashian is, where she came from or why we talk about her. That’s not because I’m particularly highbrow; The X Factor and Downton Abbey are squarely on my radar, and most of my iPod is taken up with Dolly Parton. I’ve just missed something with Kim Kardashian. What is the genesis of this famous bum? I feel like I’ve tuned in late, missed a central plank of the story and now can’t follow the plot at all. (I feel much the same way about Syria.) It’s not that I haven’t picked up bits along the way. I know she was (is?) in a reality show. I know she once did a sex tape. I know she’s married to a rapper. Still, it doesn’t gel: the level of fame, the 45 million Twitter followers, the mainstream British newspaper coverage. I feel like I’m staring at a cup of flour, a cup of cocoa powder and a cup of sugar, and not understanding how it became a cake. Where is the egg? What bound this together? I’ve seen the butt, but I can’t see the butter. Truth is, I haven’t felt any particular need to investigate Kim Kardashian further. There was no shame, for me, in my ignorance. (In that way, if in no other, she differs from Syria.) I assumed it would be slightly ridiculous for someone like me – fashion-averse, middle-class and in all statistical likelihood middle-aged – to know much about Kim Kardashian anyway. I’m not meant to be interested. I’d look silly. You might just as well say that Harriet Harman is interested in the Kardashians. That was my position – until last Tuesday morning. Last Tuesday morning is when Harriet Harman announced on Good Morning Britain: “I am an expert on the Kardashians.” Had I been holding a cartoon cup of coffee, I would have choked on it. “I think, if you step back,” continued Harman, “the overall message that comes out of the Kardashian women is that they are kind of going to make their own decisions, make their own way in the world… There’s a kind of bravery and a pioneering – oh my God, what am I saying here? – a pioneering spirit to them.” Oh my God, Harriet, what are you saying here? It’s practically the punchline to a joke. “That’s like Harriet Harman being a fan of Kim Kardashian!” Here is an alternative point of view. Kim Kardashian leads a new cultural movement that tells young women their aspirations should be about money, jewels, furs and cars, and showing their arse to people is a good route to get there. Right in the skeletal teeth of our historical sisters who were forced to sell their bodies from powerlessness, she demonstrates that even a powerful woman has not much else to sell. This she has in common with Rihanna and Nicki Minaj and all those singers who strip off and boast about how their booty brings booty. But Kim Kardashian is worse because, the daughter of a millionaire lawyer, she was born lucky, and – having been able to choose anything – she chose nudity, vanity, posing and a visible obsession with the trappings of wealth. Thus she dupes a generation of poorer, unluckier girls who do not have rich, entitled backgrounds and, having shown off their arses, will find that this does not lead to a nourishing career after all. I’m not saying that’s what I think. I don’t know if that’s what I think. But God knows I need that to be what Harriet Harman thinks. Harriet Harman, scourge of Page 3, loves the Kardashian message? Christ alive! That’s like hearing Arthur Scargill say “Actually, you know what, on reflection: screw the miners. Live in the now!” Quizzed on her apparently conflicting views, Harman said she preferred the Kardashian roadshow to Page 3 because “It’s an issue of control, actually… I get the sense of the Kardashians that they are in control of their own agenda.” But Linda Lusardi and Sam Fox and Maria Whittaker and all the other Page 3 Stunnas would have said, at the time, that they were in control of theirs. And they probably were. It isn’t about control. It’s about getting your bum out. And I’m not saying they shouldn’t; I don’t know if they shouldn’t. But God knows I need Harriet Harman to think they shouldn’t. She was the balance. A handful of readers might remember that, back in the day, I directed a porn film and wrote a book about it. They might feel queasy at the whiff of high horse. But, as I said in that book, I see a healthy place for the old-fashioned “hardcore and adults-only”. It’s the new “soft-core and everywhere” which might diminish us all. Or might not! I don’t know for certain that young women’s role models shouldn’t dance around with their bums out. I just know that I need Harriet Harman to know that they shouldn’t. Whither consistency? Why change tack now? If Harman wants to come across as light-hearted, easy-going, fun-loving and lowbrow, I’m afraid that ship’s long sailed. What she did have was a clear character and a logical moral line: rare traits in modern politics. Which adviser told her that, of all the attributes the public associate with Harriet Harman, the one she really needed to slough off was her credibility? WTF, Harriet?
